Summary of amendments/ Record documents superseded by:
Mabel Odonkor Dr. Jonathan Wong Dr. Aroon Lal
MSE Kidney Consultants. Supersedes: SUH CL47 POL - Management of Hyperkalemia - Clinical Practice Guideline CCP 3.1 – Clinical Care Pathway: Management of hyperkalaemia in adult patients

data.text: Contents
Introduction
This is a clinical care pathway which details the management of acute hyperkalaemia in adults in hospital.

Hyperkalaemia is defined as a serum potassium concentration [K+] above 5.5 mmol/L. Absolute serum K+ level as well as the rate of rise of K+ value determines the complication e.g. those with massive tissue destruction (burns or crush injuries) may be at risk of the consequences of hyperkalaemia at lower plasma levels, due to the rate of change in K+ concentration.

The severity of hyperkalaemia must be established before initiating therapy. Ensure this is not an artefact (e.g. due to haemolysis). If pseudo-hyperkalaemia is suspected, please perform simultaneous measurements of plasma K+ in a lithium heparin (plasma) and in a
clotted (serum) specimen.
All patients presenting with hyperkalaemia should undergo a comprehensive medical and drug history and clinical examination to determine the cause of hyperkalaemia.

Acutely unwell patient should be assessed using Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability and Exposure (ABCDE) approach and close monitoring should be done, as guided by National Early Warning Scoring (NEWS) system.
Scope
The purpose of this Clinical Care Pathway (CCP) is to advise Trust staff on how to manage adult patients with hyperkalaemia:
This pathway is not applicable for the following groups of patients
Patients under 18 years old
Patients who are in intensive therapy units
Re-feeding syndrome
Patients that require intramuscular or subcutaneous administration
Patients with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA)
Role & Responsibilities within the Trust
Individual responsibilities (i.e. Committees)
Renal directorate
Ensure governance structure and systems in place for monitoring and reporting hyperkalaemia, and managing severe hyperkalaemia needing direct care under the renal service
Individual responsibilities (i.e. Chief Executive)
Medical Directors: responsible for ensuring that all consultants aware of and comply with this policy.
Consultant in charge of patients' care: ensure that the patient under their care has the appropriate care that is expected for patient that has hyperkalaemia.
Junior Medical Staff:
Ensure that appropriate pathways are executed
Ensure clear documentation in the notes, including the minimum entry for quality improvement processes.
Key Elements of Policy
Causes of Hyperkalaemia
4.1.1 Pseudohyperkalaemia
Haemolysis
Prolonged transit time to the laboratory or poor storage conditions
Difficult venepuncture
Marked leukocytosis, erythrocytosis
4.1.2 Acute kidney injury (AKI)
4.1.3 Chronic kidney disease (CKD)
4.1.4 Drugs
Potassium sparing diuretics e.g. amiloride
Aldosterone antagonists e.g. spironolactone
ACE inhibitors and angiotensin II receptor blockers
Potassium containing laxatives e.g. macrogol, Kleanprep®, Fybogel®
4.1.5 Acidosis
4.1.6 Mineralocorticoid deficiency (e.g. Addison's disease)
4.1.7 Endogenous causes e.g. tumour lysis syndrome, trauma, burns, rhabdomyolysis
4.1.8 Treatment is guided by both serum potassium level and the patient's clinical condition.
Treatment of hyperkalaemia

4.2.1 All patients with hyperkalaemia should have an urgent 12-lead ECG performed on admission (prior to receiving treatment for hyperkalaemia). If there were changes in the initial ECG, a repeat ECG should be done immediately following treatment to see if they have resolved.
4.2.2 ECG changes may include: absent/flattened P wave, tall ‘tented' T waves, bradycardia, increased PR interval, widened QRS complex, ‘sine wave' pattern, VT, VF, asystole.
4.2.3 Figure 1: Five key steps in the treatment of hyperkalaemia (UK Renal Association 2014)

data.url: MSECCP-500 MSE Management of hyperkalaemia in adults 1.0.003.png

data.text: 4.2.4 STEP 1 - Cardiovascular protection (reduce cardiac cell membrane excitability)
4.2.5 Intravenous calcium chloride or calcium gluconate should be given to patients in the presence of ECG changes. This treatment does not affect potassium levels.
4.2.6 Give either:
ml 10% calcium gluconate (6.8 mmol Ca2+) IV over 15 minutes OR
ml 10% calcium chloride (6.8 mmol Ca2+) IV over 5 - 10 minutes
4.2.7 Dose can be repeated after 5 - 10 minutes if hyperkalaemic ECG changes persist and repeated later as required for recurrence of ECG changes.
4.2.8 Calcium salts are irritant to veins – monitor injection site closely. Use large peripheral vein if a central venous access device is unavailable.
4.2.9 STEP 2 - Shift K+ from plasma into cells to reduce serum potassium concentration
4.2.10 In severe hyperkalaemia (serum K+ ≥ 6.5 mmol/L): treatment should be initiated with or
without ECG changes.
4.2.11 In moderate hyperkalaemia (K+ 6.0 - 6.4 mmol/L): treatment should be considered and guided by clinical scenario, ECG and rate of rise.
a) Insulin and glucose infusion
Give 10 units soluble insulin (e.g. Actrapid) in 50 ml glucose 50% over 15 minutes with regular capillary blood glucose checks (see step 4).
Effective within:  - 30 minutes
Duration of action: 4 - 6 hours
There is a risk of hypoglycaemia post infusion and patients should have regular glucose monitoring (see treatment algorithm)
Give 10% glucose by infusion at 50mL/hr (25g) for 5 hours in patients with pre-treatment blood glucose <7.0 mmol/L
b) Nebulised salbutamol

Nebulised salbutamol (10 - 20mg) should only be used as an adjuvant therapy in severe hyperkalemia (K+ ≥ 6.5 mmol/L). It should be used with caution in patients with cardiovascular disease. The effect of salbutamol is dose-dependent. A further dose may be given if necessary.
Effective within:  - 60 minutes; max. effect should be seen 90 minutes after dose.
Duration of action: 4 - 6 hours
STEP 3 - Remove K+ from the body
a) Severe hyperkalaemia – oral potassium binders

4.2.12 Highly selective oral potassium binders reduce free concentration of free potassium in the gastrointestinal tract and promoting faecal potassium excretion. The use of oral potassium binders should be used as add-on therapy for the treatment of severe hyperkalaemia (serum K+ ≥6.5mmol/L). The onset of action is 4-7 hours after administration and should not replace or be used solely for emergency treatment of hyperkalaemia. Two oral potassium binders are available:-

4.2.13 Serum potassium levels should be monitored regularly during treatment. Typically normokalaemia is achieved within 24 to  hours. If normokalaemia is not achieved after 72 hours other treatments should be considered.
4.2.14 Administration of sodium zirconium cyclosilicate and patiromer should be separated by 3 hours from other oral medicinal products.
4.2.15 Note potential clinically relevant drug interaction due to effects on gastric pH. e.g. atorvastatin, azole antifungals, dabigatran and furosemide. For full list refer to drug SmPC.
b) Mild – Moderate hyperkalaemia - Calcium Resonium®

4.2.16 Calcium resonium is not recommended for use in the emergency management of severe hyperkalemia but short-term use may be considered in patients with moderate hyperkalemia (serum K 6.0-6.4mmol/L). It is poorly tolerated and should not be used together with Sodium zirconium cyclosilicate (Lokelma®) or Patiromer (Veltassa®). Use should usually be restricted to a maximum of 2 days and should be stopped once K+ is normalised.
4.2.17 Oral:  g every 6 - 8 hours in a suspension of water or syrup in the ratio of 3 - 4 ml/ g of resin.
4.2.18 Co-prescribe lactulose with oral resin to avoid constipation and the formation of bezoars which could perforate the gut.
4.2.19 Haemodialysis may be required to remove potassium in resistant cases, particularly in patients with acute kidney injury (AKI) or pre-existing chronic kidney disease.
4.2.20 STEP 4 - Monitor K+ and glucose
4.2.21 Serum potassium should be assessed at least 1, 2, 4, 6 and  hours after identification and treatment of hyperkalaemia, to assess efficacy of treatment and look for rebound
4.2.22 hyperkalaemia after the initial response to treatment. Venous blood gas (VBG) can be used for the purpose of monitoring.

4.2.23 Blood glucose concentration should be monitored at regular intervals (0, 15, 30, 60, 90, 120, 180, 240, 360, 480 and 720 minutes) for up to  hours after administration of insulin- glucose infusion in all patients with hyperkalaemia.
4.2.24 STEP 5 – Prevent recurrence
4.2.25 Primary prevention steps for patients with CKD include regular blood monitoring, careful drug prescribing and dietary advice.

4.2.26 Assessing risk factors for the development of hyperkalaemia and stopping potential precipitants e.g. nephrotoxic drugs, are examples of secondary prevention. A follow- up plan needs to be made.
Patient Monitoring
4.3.1 Continuous cardiac monitoring with 3-lead ECG is recommended for all patients with:
Serum K+ ≥ 6.5 mmol/L
Features of hyperkalaemia on 12-lead ECG
Serum K+ value between 6.0 - 6.4 mmol/L and who are clinically unwell or in whom a rapid rise in serum K+ is anticipated
4.3.2 Extravasation of calcium may cause tissue damage. If extravasation occurs, stop administration of the medicine; aspirate the residual fluid through the cannula. Elevate the limb.
4.3.3 Blood glucose and K+ should be monitored as in step

4.3.4 Patients with hyperkalaemia will need to be nursed in a monitored bed on an acute ward by adequately trained nursing staff. They should not be nursed in a ‘medical outlying ward'. HDU admission may be required for patients with poor National Early Warning System (NEWS) scores.
Escalation of Care

4.4.1  Patients with severe hyperkalemia (serum potassium > 6.5 mmol/L) should be referred to the renal team for an urgent opinion, guided by the clinical scenario and its persistence after initial medical treatment. Referral should also be made to renal or intensive care for severe hyperkalaemia in the presence of severe AKI with oliguria and for those who failed to respond to initial treatment.
Emergency Management of

Monitoring and Audit

data.text: Approval and Implementation

This clinical care pathway will be reviewed and approved by the renal consultants across the MSE group of hospitals. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.

This will be implemented with immediate effect from its agreement date. This document will be available electronically on the Trust intranet. Advice and support on the implementation of this policy is available via the site department of pharmacy.
Equality Impact Assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 1)

What are you proposing to change?
Management of hyperkalaemia to be in line with national guidance
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)
National Patient Safety Alert for hyperkalaemia
Who benefits from this change and how?
Patients who have this common medical complication will have clear consistent treatment in line with national guidance
Is anyone likely to suffer any negative impact as a result of this change? If no, please record reasons here and sign and date this assessment. If yes, please complete a full EIA.
a) Will you be undertaking any consultation as part of this change?
Discussed with MSE Renal Consultant body. Once approved, we will encourage adoption by all medical staff
